This study design makes sense for evaluating the safety and efficacy of TTFields as a treatment for leptomeningeal metastases from breast cancer. By assessing response based on MRI, we can confirm any changes in the tumor burden, without using invasive means.

In the second study arm, patients will receive treatment as in the first arm, but with the addition of the NovoTTF device. In this arm, patients will be treated with both systemic therapy and TTF. This might include another form of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or other treatment currently used for patients with leptomeningeal metastasis. ACRONYM = Acute study of Cognitively assisted Robot therapy to enhance Arm and hand performance AFTER stroke; Efficacy to support Clinical practice ACRT-ACUTE-2 is a double-blind, multicenter, randomized parallel-group, 90-day active treatment, 90-day extinction-maintenance phase, phase II, double dummy, parallel group, pragmatic, clinically adaptive, multicenter, active and sham rTMS versus an active and sham TMS plus education comparison trial. ACRT=Arm and Hand Rehabilitation using the neuroSkyTM Robot device and Virtual REality for Stroke Survivors-2 THEORY This is a prospective, double-blinded, single-center, crossover, repeated-measures, randomized trial assessing the efficacy of Robotic Assisted Wearable ExosuitTM (RAWEx) in reducing energy expenditure and enhancing movement economy during level walking over a range of walking velocities. Target Population The target clinical population is individuals with lower limb motor deficits resulting from chronic stroke. Clinical Rehabilitation Testing. The study subjects will be recruited from referrals of post- Stroke adults seeking to improve their gait and mobility. This study consists of two parallel groups. Both groups will wear an RAWEx suit and perform overground walking under three experimental conditions at three velocities for four days per week for one week. The order of the three conditions will be randomized across subjects ﬁxed for the full study. Assessments: We will use indirect calorimetry to measure the oxygen and CO 2 exchange between the subject and the environment to determine resting energy expenditure as well as during walking at walking speed conditions. We will measure the amount of oxygen consumed by the participant wearing the RAWEx suit while they walk, and by the participant wearing the control suit while the RAWEx suit is worn. We will also measure heart rate during the walking tasks. In addition, we will use actigraphy and a Berg motion sensor to analyze the power output.
This study is a prospective, randomized, blinded study designed to compare the functional abilities of neurobotic® Lokomotion

model_response: Nope, that's it. I've just designed the study arms for a clinical trial on the relationship between post-wash total motile sperm count and pregnancy rate among infertile patients undergoing intrauterine insemination.
This study arm is necessary to compare the outcomes of intrauterine insemination with those without it.

Study Arm 2: Hypothetical intervention Based on recent studies showing a relationship between the success of intrauterine insemination and post-wash total motile sperm count, we hypothesize that a higher post-wash total motile sperm count results in a higher pregnancy rate. We want to test this hypothesis by giving intrauterine insemination to patients with low post-wash total motile sperm count, and comparing the pregnancy rate in this group to the pregnancy rate of the standard study arm. This group will represent what happens if we were to increase the sperm count in the insemination procedure.
This group will help us assess the impact of post-wash TMSC > 3 x 10^6 on the success of intrauterine insemination.

Study Arm 3: Intrauterine insemination with pre-wash TMSC <3 x 10^6. The Intervention/treatment is the same as study arm 2, but the pre-wash total motile sperm count is below the recommended threshold of 3 x 10^6.

This arm is designed to evaluate the pregnancy rates of patients with a low post-wash total motile sperm count in accordance with current guidelines, as a basis for further study and possible revision of the recommended threshold. The lower the post-wash TMSC, the more likely that assisted reproductive technology will be required to achieve a pregnancy, and the higher the rate of multiple births will be.  The implications for policy and practice are clear, thus the need to include a patient population with a post-wash TMSC less than 3 x 10^6 for assessment of pregnancy rates at that threshold.

Study 1: Treatment effects The control group receives standard clinical practice, while the two study groups receive the experimental treatment. 1 Study 2: Treatment effect versus underlying disease/covariate The control and treatment groups are the same as in Study 1. 2 Study 3: Treatment effect versus crossover Since Study 1 and Study 2 are similar, only the differences between Study 1 and Study 3 need to be described. Pre- to post-treatment change: Patients assigned to the treatment group are treated with the experimental treatment, so the change between the two assessments is due to the treatment. Within-subjects covariate: Patients in the control group are "crossovered" into the treatment group so they are still being treated the standard way while the treatment group is receiving the experimental treatment. The within-subjects covariate of interest is the previous baseline measurement for the patients in the control group. The within-subjects crossover design prevents this group of patients from being compared with themselves. Crossover: The within-subjects covariate is a factor that is fixed over time, so any repeated measures are the covariate for themselves.

Participants in both treatment arms will have similar inclusion/exclusion criteria.

Participants assigned to the control arm will receive rituximab and chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, oral cyclophosphamide, 750 mg/m2 on days 1, 8, and 29 of 3 out of 6 21-day cycles. For the experimental arm, the study group will include untreated elderly patients with Stage 1 or 2 Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma who are healthy enough to receive chemo+CD20 monoclonal antibody therapy. The treatment for Part 1A will consist of escalating doses of Odronextamab + CHOP (Rituximab + Cyclophosphamide + Doxorubicin + Prednisone). The treatment for Part 1B will be optimization of the dose in Part 1A based on safety and efficacy evaluations. For the control/comparator arm, the study group will include the same type of healthy and similarly-stricken patients as the experimental group. The treatment will be Rituximab in combination with CHOP chemotherapy.

The control arm (Rituximab + CHOP) will consist of patients receiving Rituximab (a B-cell-targeting monoclonal antibody) in combination with the same chemotherapy, CHOP, as in the experimental arm. This group will receive the current standard treatment. This control arm allows us to measure the efficacy and safety of Odronextamab relative to the current standard of care.

The design for each arm seeks to minimize the potential for bias and ensure the safety and efficacy of each treatment. The experimental arm incorporates dose escalation in the first phase and dose optimization in the second phase to optimize exposure to the Odronextamab and CHOP combination and to ensure the safety of the participants. There are several key aspects to consider when designing a randomized clinical trial in urologic medicine. One set of criteria that has been used for many years is the "Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (CONSORT) Extension Statement". These include items aimed at improving the reporting of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) with a particular focus on clinical trials of medicinal products.
The CONSORT Extension Statement aims to improve reporting of the design, conduct, and reporting of RCTs of nonpharmacological, noninterventions trials, such as surgical trials. Recently, an extension of the original statement was released to help ensure rigor and transparency in the reporting of studies of measurement and diagnostic accuracy, the so-called "The CONSORT ESA."
Another similar initiative is the "The Recommendations for Reporting Urological Protective Equipment (RReME) checklist" which "provides a framework for authors to report the design and conduct of urological protective equipment trials, including single centre studies and multi-center studies, randomized trials, observational studies and non-comparative studies, in the form of a pre-registration form, as a checklist, or in the form of a structured abstract.
An extension to the RReME consensus statement was developed at the 2nd International MEta-Analysis Of Urologic PROtective Equipment (META-UROPE) Workshop. Certainly! The intervention in the experimental arm will involve participants using the ISO-101 device. This is a wearable wrist device that aims to improve orthostatic hypotension by minimizing the postural change in blood pressure. This trial will take place at a single center and participants will be recruited from the outpatient hypertension clinic. Eligible participants include those with a clinically diagnosed orthostatic hypotension, as detected by a drop in systolic blood pressure of ≥20 mmHg within 3 minutes of standing up, as well as those with a resting diastolic blood pressure ≤50 mmHg. Participants will be excluded if they have a prior history of syncope, a recent history of heart attack, renal disease, a pacemaker, pregnant or breastfeeding women, or any other contraindications for isosceles, such as severe claustrophobia, depression, or fever at the time of assessment. Participants in both arms will be instructed to maintain their usual antihypertensive medications throughout the trial. During the study, the participants will be asked to wear the device for 14 days. On visit 1, the participants will undergo a 10-minute battery of tests, which will include measurements of vital signs, calibration of the isosceles, and then a tilt test, where the participant will stay still for five minutes, then stand up and their blood pressure and heart rate will be recorded over the next 10 minutes. They will get to wear the blood pressure monitor for another 3~ days and keep a diary of each 30-minute period where they get up from a sitting or lying down position to stand. On their final visit, which will be at day 14, they will have another round of the above tests and they will take home the isosceles and will be asked to return it by mail. Participants will be asked not to modify their physical activity or medication intake during the trial. They will also be asked to complete the Symptomatic Orthostatic Hypotension Quality of Life Questionnaire, the Short form of the EQ-5D Health Status Questionnaire, the Short Physical General Health Scale and the Nottingham Facial Cognitive Impair

The No Intervention: Control arm is important to compare the effects of the ISO-101 device. By comparing the results of the Control and Experimental arms, we can more effectively evaluate the role of the ISO-101 device in treating orthostatic hypotension.

A third group will receive a combination of Metformin and Cabergoline. This will allow us to compare the effects of the combination therapy to the effects of Cabergoline alone. We can name this group Group 3 (M&C). The participants in this group will receive Metformin 500 MG twice daily and Cabergoline 0.5 MG orally, once weekly for a duration of 90 days.

The participants in the control group will receive a matching placebo for Metformin or Cabergoline. We will then measure the ovarian volume, hormone levels, glucose levels, and other parameters of interest at the beginning of the study and at regular intervals throughout the trial. We expect to see a reduction in ovarian volume in the treatment groups relative to the control group, which would suggest a beneficial effect of both Metformin and Cabergoline on ovarian volume. We may also see a reduction in androgens and an increase in estrogen levels, which would be indicative of the effects of Metformin and Cabergoline on the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. We should also see a decrease in LH and FSH levels, which would suggest an improvement in ovarian function. Glucose levels should also improve in the treatment groups relative to the control group. model_response: I suggest conducting a crossover design. On entry, all patients will receive the fixed combination of Perindopril 4 mg / Indapamide 1.25 mg plus Amlodipine 5 mg for at least 4 weeks to establish a blood pressure baseline. After that, you can either withdraw the active comparator arm or keep it open for early titration. You can then switch all participants to the experimental arm by withdrawing the active comparator and adding the fixed combination of Perindopril 5 mg / Indapamide 1.25 mg / Amlodipine 5 mg at the same dose they were receiving in the active comparator. The switch can be done gradually or immediately, and the duration of the switch depends on the patient's response. This will allow us to compare the efficacy and safety of the experimental arm against the active comparator while minimizing the risk of carryover effects from the fixed combination used in the active comparator. This design is illustrated below.

After Month 2, the treatment in both arms will be fixed. We can switch to the fixed combination in the experimental arm, and discontinue the free combination in the active comparator arm. For both arms, we'll continue to monitor their blood pressure until study completion at Month 6. Are there any other specific parameters you'd like me to address?
The trial will last for 12 months.

I will provide you with the full study arms as follows: Experimental arm: Perindopril 5 mg / indapamide 1.25 mg / amlodipine 5 mg Fixed combination: Perindopril 4 mg / indapamide 1.25 mg plus amlodipine 5 mg Control arm: Indapamide 1.25 mg plus amlodipine 5 mg In both arms, the blood pressure targets are: SBP < 140 mmHg and DBP < 90 mmHg. The first goal is to confirm the non-inferiority of the fixed combination to the control over 6 months. In addition, patients on the fixed combination arm will undergo an up-titration if their blood pressure is below 140/90 mmHg. This is a randomized double-blind placebo-controlled study with a 2:1 ratio of treatment to placebo. The primary end point of the study is the non-inferiority of the fixed combination to the control arm over 6 months. The secondary end points include incidence of hypertension-related complications, incidence of new onset of cardiovascular events, and the safety profile of the fixed combination compared to the control arm.

The following is the full list of study arms that we have designed for the study: Study Arm Descriptions Experimental: Video-game based therapy Arm Intervention: Participants in this arm will receive a combination of standard physiotherapy and video-game-based therapy. Conventional: Conventional therapy alone Arm Intervention: Participants in this arm will receive only conventional physiotherapy, which will occur twice a week, each session lasting 45 minutes. Both the arms will follow the protocols suggested by the physiotherapist. Our rationale for choosing these study arms was based on previous studies that had demonstrated the efficacy of video-game based therapy in improving upper limb function in individuals with cerebral palsy. We also wanted to control for the effects of conventional physiotherapy, which is the current standard of care for individuals with cerebral palsy. The aim of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a novel combination of Dostarlimab, Bevacizumab, and Niraparib in platinum-resistant ovarian cancer. Primary ovarian cancer is the leading cause of death among gynecologic malignancies in the United States. Despite advances in diagnosis and treatment, 40% of women with ovarian cancer are diagnosed at a point of platinum resistance. We previously identified a combination of Dostarlimab, an anti- PD-1 checkpoint inhibitor, and Niraparib as a promising therapeutic combination in preclinical models of platinum resistant ovarian cancer. We are investigating this combination in a Phase 1b study.  In the proposed first cohort of the study, eligible participants will receive Dostarlimab at a dose of 10 mg/kg every 3 weeks in combination with Niraparib (3PARP, 200mg bid) for 21 days every 28 days. Participants will receive up to 5 doses of Dostarlimab/Niraparib every 28 days in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable side effects. The aim of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination of Dostarlimab, Bevacizumab, and Niraparib in participants with platinum resistant ovarian cancer.

The other arm of this trial will be the control arm, or placebo arm, with the following details: "Control: observation only - no treatment/intervention." Participants will receive no treatment/intervention other than standard care.

Hi and thanks for the questions!
Please note: These are questions were solicited in an interactive question-and-answer session. Since they were asked by a participant, i.e. someone who is actually preparing to present a poster on this topic, I have answered them as I would answer them if I were preparing and presenting a poster on this research. It is definitely not intended as advice for "first-time" posters, i.e. those who are just preparing to submit their first poster presentation. There's plenty of other good sites to check for "beginner" advice.
These posts are presented as-is, with no additional editing or further explanation.
Designing a poster is an interactive process in which the poster "tells the story" of a scientific project or study. The title and design should therefore clearly reflect the objective of the research.
The title is likely to change as the research progresses, but the title

Excellent suggestion! A second participant group related to regional anesthesia is a great idea. In fact, we might want to include a third participant group related to a control or comparator intervention/treatment. Let's focus on designing the study arms and include additional anesthesia-related groups. Would a participant group receiving general anesthesia with or without adjunct medications be helpful for this research question? Adding these study arms would help differentiate among the potential causes of desflurane rise time variation.
Another good idea! Including a comparison to a different inhalational anesthetic will provide even more information about the effects of desflurane. Now, how should we design this study arm?

- Intervention/Treatment: General anesthesia using sevoflurane.
- Reasoning: Including a participant group related to general anesthesia allows for a comparison between different anesthesia techniques. By using sevoflurane as the inhalational agent, the researchers can observe the differences in desflurane onset time with respect to the other methodology.

Of course! A great candidate for the participant group would be patients with renal insufficiency. For the intervention/treatment, we could study desflurane induction, as desflurane may have different effects in kidney-insufficient patients compared to other inhaled anesthetics.  With this information, the 3-arm design for this study would look like this:  
- Participant Group/Arm: Patients with renal insufficiency scheduled for elective surgery.
- Intervention/Treatment: Desflurane induction.
- Control/Arm: sevoflurane induction or alternative anesthetic agent (eg, propofol, nitrous oxide, etc.)
- Comparator/Arm: sevoflurane induction.
The idea is to compare the impact of desflurane on end-tidal desflurane level in subjects with renal insufficiency versus control subjects with different inhaled anesthetics. I think that this design is not only scientifically interesting, but may also be clinically relevant, as some inhaled anesthetics may have different pharmacokinetics in patients with renal insufficiency.

Maitland mobilization is a type of articular method, wherein the practitioner uses short lever arm muscle energy techniques and low-energy passive movements to help restore movement. The treatment is not painful or forceful. It's a low-load, low-intensity approach.

Interferential therapy works by delivering two electrical currents of different frequencies and intensities in alternating directions to the affected joint. The parameters that will be used in the study include frequency of 20Hz, intensity of 40mA, and a treatment duration of 20 minutes.

Mulligan's mobilization techniques include the following components: The practitioner will stand at the side of the patient, holding their hand behind the knee at the popliteal fossa at a 75-90-degree angle. The practitioner will apply pressure with their fingers and move their hand towards the front of the knee, following the leg and knee joint line. The practitioner will continue moving their hand away towards the lateral side of the knee until a click or 'pop' is achieved. This process will be repeated on the lateral side. The practitioner will apply pressure with his or her lateral fingers on the posterior fibers of the greater trochanters of both the femur and tibia. The practitioner will stand behind the patient, with the patient's knee bent at around 30-45 degrees in a lunge position, and apply pressure over the posterior fibers of the greater trochanter of the femur and medial joints fibers of the tibia. They will then return the limb to the initial position. These procedures may be repeated on the other side of the limb.  The practitioner will follow the protocol outlined for the anterior fibers of the gluteus maximus muscle, and also for the inferior fibers of the rectus femoris and hamstrings muscles. These procedures are repeated for the patella. The practitioner and patient will stand in the initial position for the patella and repeat the same maneuvers for the inferior fibers of the rectus femoris muscles. Finally, the practitioner will repeat the same movements for the anterior fibers of the hamstring muscles. The practitioner will again repeat the patella maneuvers as outlines before.

Participants satisfying eligibility requirements will be randomized to one of two study groups. The "drug" group will follow the protocol for titration of antihypertensive medication to achieve a goal mean blood pressure of less than 130/80 mmHg, in accordance with standard American Heart Association guidelines. The "control" group will employ a 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) and 48-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) recording to assess changes in blood pressure variability over a 48-hour period. An important consideration when designing the study is naming. In this case, the treatment (vaccine) arm is the "experimental" arm and the control (placebo) is named the "experimental" arm. This naming is backwards from the convention in a medical context, but is appropriate in this case because the intent is to test the effect of the treatment, not the effect of something else on the treatment.
(Also the placebo, or "control" arm gets the designation "experimental" because it is a comparison against a not yet existing intervention, but in general the controls would be better named the "standard of care" or "disease progression" arm because the goal is to contrast progression under that condition.)

model_response: Sure. The selection criteria include: histologically or cytologically confirmed PDAC; Stage IIB to IV disease; measurable disease; ECOG performance status of 0 or 1; life expectancy greater than 12 weeks; adequate bone marrow, hepatic, and renal function; and absence of prior Cytotoxic chemotherapy, monoclonal antibody therapy, radiation therapy, or surgery for the treatment of pancreatic cancer. The criteria for exclusion are presence of metastatic disease to the brain, leptomeninges, or other organ system; uncontrolled concomitant diseases or symptoms likely to interfere with the study; major surgery anticipated within 28 days after the first date of treatment; presence of any other disease expected to interfere with the study assessments; uncontrolled psychiatric disorders; or use of any investigational drug or device within 30 days before the first dose of study therapy.

The exclusion criteria include individuals with a history of major surgery or radiation therapy within 28 days of the first dose of study therapy, concurrent treatment with another antitumor therapy, and a score of 2 or greater on the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status. Individuals with a significant cardiac disease or uncontrolled infection are also excluded. Is there anything else you need from me at this time?

The treatment arms for the trial are NALIRIFOX with or without radiotherapy. Arm A receives NALIRIFOX alone, and Arm B receives NALIRIFOX and radiation therapy. Both treatment arms involve a 4-month treatment regimen with a 6-month assessment after completion of treatment. Treatment duration for Arm A is 12 weeks (1 cycle 30 mg/m2 IVF every 3 weeks) with or without concomitant oxaliplatin given on days 1, 8, 29 of the first and second cycle. Arm B participants will receive oral capecitabine (825 mg/m2, BID) and oxaliplatin (85 mg/m2, D1, 8, 29 every 3 weeks). Once the tumor volume increases to 2 cm or greater, radiation therapy is administered in a standard fractionated course until the tumor volume reaches <2.0 cm. The radiation regimen consists of 50.4 Gy in 18 fractions every other day and may be boosted to a dose of 36 Gy in 18 fractions. Radiation will be initiated after completion of NALIRIFOX and will not commence until there is documentation of a 50% decrease in tumor bulk. I hope this provides you with all the details you need for the study arms.
